newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Koor to sell off Israel Edible Products.
newsitem.headline: Koor to sell off Israel Edible Products.

text.p: Koor Industries Ltd intends to sell its 24.5 percent stake in Israel Edible Products, a food maker, to the U.S. company CPC International, a Koor source said on Tuesday.
"In a few weeks Koor will complete the sale of its 24.5 percent holding in Israel Edible to CPC," the source told Reuters. He gave no sale price.
Israel Edible, also known as Tami, is majority-owned by CPC, which makes such products as Hellman's mayonnaise and Knorr brand soups.
Israel Edible produces about 90 percent of all retail margarine sold in Israel and also produces soups, mayonnaise, breakfast cereals and chocolate, many of the products under CPC brand names.
Koor, Israel's largest holding company, announced on Tuesday it had signed a memorandum of understanding with Greenfield Industries Inc to sell its wholly owned Hanita Metal Works to the U.S. firm.
Hanita and Greenfield both make cutting tools and related products. Greenfield is based in Augusta, Georgia.

A Koor spokesman said the sale was part of chief executive officer Benjamin Gaon's strategy to focus on Koor's core businesses: telecommunications, electronics, agrochemicals, building materials and energy distribution.
The Israeli Edible sale is part of the same streamlining strategy. Koor's other food companies include Shemen Industries, canneries and a meat processor.
The spokesman said no sale price for Hanita would be announced until due diligence was completed.
